fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Customer reports that when searching for users in Audit Log, the query requires typing the exact begining characters of the username.
On a large data sets, admins may want to search for "users" to find "confluence-users" "jira-users" and other groups, for example, and are unable at the moment.
Furthermore, unable to search for lastnames or other username usual components.

h3. Environment
Reproduced on
- Crowd 3.6 and 3.7
- Postgres

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Sample user name: utest01
 # Access Crowd, got to Audit Logs
 # In User filter, type 'test' 
 # Delete the field content and type '01'
 # Delete the field content and type 'ut'

h3. Expected Results
Find the user typing any part of the username.

h3. Actual Results
User can only be found if we start typing "ut" and so on.

The query it performs in Postgres use comparison operation {{LIKE 'string%'}} instead of {{ILIKE '%string%'}}.

Excerpt from Postgres log:
{code}
[64807]: [565-1] user=postgres,db=crowd_360,app=PostgreSQL JDBC Driver,client=127.0.0.1 LOG:  execute <unnamed>: select distinct entities1_.entity_name as col_0_0_, entities1_.entity_id as col_1_0_, entities1_.entity_type as col_2_0_ from cwd_audit_log_changeset auditlogch0_ inner join cwd_audit_log_entity entities1_ on auditlogch0_.id=entities1_.changeset_id where entities1_.entity_type=$1 and (entities1_.entity_name like $2) order by col_0_0_ ASC limit $3
[64807]: [566-1] user=postgres,db=crowd_360,app=PostgreSQL JDBC Driver,client=127.0.0.1 DETAIL:  parameters: $1 = 'USER', $2 = 'Test%', $3 = '11'
{code}

h3. Workaround
None at the moment. User name and Group name have to be typed with exact initial characters.
fields.summary: Searching Users in Audit Log Requires typing the initial characters of the username

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Customer reports that when searching for users in Audit Log, the query is case sensitive. So, varying cases in usernames, displays name and e-mails may cause them not to be found. The same applies for groups.
h3. Environment

Reproduced on
 - Crowd 3.6 and 3.7
 - Postgres

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Sample user name: Guest
 # Access Crowd, got to Audit Logs
 # In User filter, type 'guest'
 # Delete the field content and type 'Guest'
 # Delete the field content and type 'GUEST'

h3. Expected Results

Find the user typed in either lower, upper or mixed cases
h3. Actual Results

User can only be found if the username it is typed exactly as stored.

The query it performs in Postgres use comparison operation {{LIKE}} instead of {{ILIKE.}}

Excerpt from Postgres log:
{code:java}
[64807]: [565-1] user=postgres,db=crowd_360,app=PostgreSQL JDBC Driver,client=127.0.0.1 LOG:  execute <unnamed>: select distinct entities1_.entity_name as col_0_0_, entities1_.entity_id as col_1_0_, entities1_.entity_type as col_2_0_ from cwd_audit_log_changeset auditlogch0_ inner join cwd_audit_log_entity entities1_ on auditlogch0_.id=entities1_.changeset_id where entities1_.entity_type=$1 and (entities1_.entity_name like $2) order by col_0_0_ ASC limit $3
[64807]: [566-1] user=postgres,db=crowd_360,app=PostgreSQL JDBC Driver,client=127.0.0.1 DETAIL:  parameters: $1 = 'USER', $2 = 'Test%', $3 = '11'
{code}
h3. Workaround

None at the moment. User name has to be typed in exact casing as it is stored.
fields.summary: Searching in Audit Log is Case Sensitive

fields.description:
h4. Summary:

As a Crowd administrator, I would like to use OKTA SSO (SAML) for my Atlassian applications, however, my idea is to have only Crowd integration with OKTA and acting as a bridge app in between OKTA and Jira/Confluence/Bitbucket. This means that if an unauthenticated user logs to Confluence, Confluence sends an authentication request to Crowd and Crowd talks to OKTA to get the SAML Authentication done.
h4. Scenario:
 * User tries to access Confluence/Jira.
 * They reach Crowd Logon page.
 * They insert their user and password which is authenticated against the information in OKTA.
 * OKTA sends the confirmation to Crowd.
 * Crowd redirects to the application being requested.

 
h4. How does SAML Works?

Each application needs to be SAML Versed in order for them to be able to integrate with Okta. The way we establish this is by either using the Connectors provided by Okta (available for Jira and Confluence only) or through third party plugins provided by vendors such as Mini Orange(e.g).

Once that's done, we integrate those applications with Okta with the aid of those plugins as well. At this point, the applications will know that login requests should go to Okta to be processed and will also know how to read a SAML response accordingly.
h4. Considerations:

The scenario explained above seems ambiguous, since both Crowd and Okta in their scenario seem to have the same or very similar proposal which is to act as the IdP. However, even though this is similar, it can be important for some organizations or companies.
fields.summary: Crowd to support SAML as Service Provider

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Stopping Crowd spams logs with SEVERE probable memory leak warnings. These are misleading as we are shutting down the crowd.
h3. Environment

(Optional - If Applicable)
 * Tested in Crowd 3.4.4

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 #  Start Crowd by using start_crowd.sh
 #  Stop Crowd by using stop_crowd.sh

h3. Expected Results

Clean shutdown without any SEVERE logging
h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the catalina.out file:
{code:java}
10-Oct-2019 13:06:39.912 SEVERE [localhost-startStop-2] org.apache.catalina.loader.WebappClassLoaderBase.checkThreadLocalMapForLeaks The web application [crowd] created a ThreadLocal with key of type [org.springframework.core.NamedInheritableThreadLocal] (value [Current invoker bundle context]) and a value of type [org.apache.felix.framework.BundleContextImpl] (value [org.apache.felix.framework.BundleContextImpl@13879773]) but failed to remove it when the web application was stopped. Threads are going to be renewed over time to try and avoid a probable memory leak.
{code}
 
h3. Workaround

Required, if there is no workaround please state:
 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Stopping Crowd spams logs with SEVERE probable memory leak warnings

fields.description:
It would be great it would be possible when for example connecting to Microsoft AD, to add failover URLs directly in the directory connector.

When using crowd to connect to Microsoft AD today, it's possible to add failover by creating another (identical) directory and then adding them both to the applications directories. 

However this setup have many drawbacks. 
 In our setup we have a global Microsoft AD (which are available at 4 URLs/IPs), and in our setup for our country it fetches only "our" users from the AD (2000 of total 40.000). We also have our "jira" groups created locally in the crowd instance.

Using the above approach gives the following issues:
 * To have multiple directories with the same config (except the URL), is errorprone and its easy to do a mistake with one directory when updating its config. 
 * Since all groups are created in the primary directory, we *must* use directory aggregation in order to have the groups if the users logs in from the failover group. However directory aggregation is not wanted for our other directories with customer users.
 * It´s not possible from the failover directory to filter out who can authenticate (e.g. users in the confluence-users group only, instead everyone must be able to authenticate in crowd --> we need to have higher crowd license than nescessary.
 * Crowd must duplicate the same users since it need to fetch them again to all directories, unless using delegated authentication directory. However with delegated directory, the application can´t longer use the  *incremental synchronization.*
fields.summary: Make it possible to add failover URLs in the _Directory_ Connector

fields.description:
Currently when there is an issue with the user objects in LDAP, and Crowd is unable to resolve it, the whole synchronisation process stops and fails. Stopping synchronisation is to help prevent further user or group errors, if synchronisation is allowed to continue. 

We do have instances, however, where administrators prefer that a partial success of synchronisation is better than aborting the synchronisation altogether. 
h5. Suggestion

Provide an option that allows administrators to toggle between allowing partial synchronisation(skipping erroneous user records in LDAP), or staying with the current behaviour of aborting synchronisation altogether.
fields.summary: Provide an option to gracefully handle synchronisation errors.

fields.description:
Currently the following document suggests using {{com.atlassian.crowd}} and setting it to Debug level, to help debug the crowd package.

While enabling this for troubleshooting synchonisation would work, the amount of logs being recorded is huge as the package will include all the other child packages that might not be related to synchronisation troubleshooting
 * [Logging and Profiling|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/logging-and-profiling-24248601.html]

At the moment, {{com.atlassian.crowd}} reads:
{quote}This is the parent of the crowd package loggers. Any children which do not have a level assigned to them will inherit the level from their parent. This logger should be set to DEBUG only if you are investigating SSO issues.
{quote}
For synchronisation issues, it is best to enable specific child packages (instead of the {{com.atlassian.crowd}} parent package) related to the synchronisation process such as:
{code:java}
com.atlassian.crowd.dao.directory
com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap
com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations
com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DirectoryCacheImplUsingChangeOperations{code}
Enabling the above will only display relevant information regarding synchronisation. 

h5. Suggestion:
Adding a section in the above document specific to troubleshooting synchronisation errors would help speed up troubleshooting.
fields.summary: Enhance Crowd Logging and Profiling document to include a section on troubleshooting synchronisation errors effectively

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Crowd removes non local groups from remote directory even when 'Manage groups locally' is on. This is change in behavior as pre 3.6 Crowd did not attempt to remove group from remote.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Connect Crowd to remote directory and select 'Manage groups locally'
 # Synchronize groups to Crowd
 # Remove one of groups that was synchronized

h3. Expected Results

There should be information that group cannot be removed
h3. Actual Results

Remote group is removed
h3. Workaround

Make sure that the user account used for directory connection does not have permissions to remove remote groups
fields.summary: Crowd removes non local groups from remote directory even when 'Manage groups locally' is on

The email message may contain configuration information about the application that the plugin is installed into.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#b2d4ff|titleBGColor=#b2d4ff|bgColor=#eaf1fc}
Microsoft has not released any major updates for IE11 since 2015, and has [recently discouraged the use of IE11 as a default browser|https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/Windows-IT-Pro-Blog/The-perils-of-using-Internet-Explorer-as-your-default-browser/ba-p/331732].

To allow us to continue to take advantage of modern web standards to deliver improved functionality and the best possible user experience across all of our products, we have decided to end support for IE11. *Crowd 4.1 is the last IE11-supported version.*

End of support means we will not fix bugs that are specific to IE11, and will begin to introduce features that aren't compatible with this browser.

Find out more about this change from our [announcement|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Feedback-Forum-articles/Retiring-IE11-support-for-Atlassian-cloud-server-and-data-center/ba-p/1185312].

If you have questions or concerns about this change, please comment on this issue.
{panel}
fields.summary: Plans to end support for IE11

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Changing license to one with user limit lower than current number of users you have results with losing access to Crowd
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to _Licensing_ page
 # Fill _license key_ field with license that has a user limit lower than current number of users you have
 # Click _save_

h3. Expected Results

Crowd won't accept this license and show an error about that the license you're providing has a user limit lower than current number of users you have.

This is how it works when you provide an expired license. The behaviour in this case should be similar.
h3. Actual Results

License key is accepted. You lose access to Crowd.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Changing license to one with user limit lower than current number of users you have results with losing access to Crowd

fields.description:
Logging and Profiling for Crowd has a "Changing the Destination of the Crowd Log File", that mentions the following, when editing log4.properties file:
{quote} # Look for the {{org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender}} entry in the '*Log File Locations*' section of the file. This appender controls the default logging destination described [above|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/logging-and-profiling-24248601.html#LoggingandProfiling-defaultdestination].{quote}
The issue is, the class \{{org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender }}does not exist in the default log4j.properties file. That leads to a confusion on how to properly adjust logging settings.

 Documentation link: [https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/logging-and-profiling-24248601.html]

If possible, please add detailed instructions on how to change the log file destination and also how to create a new file appender.

An idea would be to use Confluence's log4j.properties file header below as starting point:
{quote}
{code:java}###
# LOGGING LOCATION AND APPENDER
#
# Here we define the default appender which after bootstrap will log to logs/atlassian-confluence.log
# within your configured confluence.home. Prior to that, logging will be to the console.
#
# Use the ConsoleAppender for development to leave the logging configuration up to the app server/IDEA.
#
# If you want to log to a different location uncomment the RollingFileAppender line and the File setting
# as instructed below.
###
log4j.appender.confluencelog=com.atlassian.confluence.logging.ConfluenceHomeLogAppender
# Comment the above line and uncomment the following 2 lines if you want to log to a specific location
#log4j.appender.confluencelog=org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender
#log4j.appender.confluencelog.File=${catalina.home}/logs/atlassian-confluence.log{code}{quote}
fields.summary: Logging and profiling - Changing the Destination of the Crowd Log File section needs adjustment
Crowd default log4j.properties is defined in a way that it omits some initial levels of the logged classes.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When calculating license usage for users that have empty external ids the calculation will fail on the application's side with a NullPointerException.

This can typically happen in directories with a nullable external id attribute by definition or when the external id attribute was misconfigured. Internal directories generally should not be affected by this issue as default external ids are generated for those directories.

While Crowd does augment external ids provided to applications, it will relay a null or empty external id as a null, so the issue can occur both when the directory is defined in Jira/Confluence/BBS as well as when it's a directory defined in the Crowd defined for that application.

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Setup a directory which has at least one user with an empty external id in Jira/Confluence/BBS
 # Setup license monitoring for that application

h3. Expected Results

The license usage is calculated.
h3. Actual Results

License calculation fails on the connected application's side with an exception like this one:
{code}
2019-08-21 17:18:20,008 ERROR [Caesium-1-1] [impl.schedule.caesium.JobRunnerWrapper] runJob Scheduled job COLLECT-LICENSE-USAGE#PanopticonCollectLicenseUsageData failed to run java.lang.NullPointerException: externalId is marked @NonNull but is null at com.atlassian.plugins.license.model.PluginLicensedUser$PluginLicensedUserBuilder.externalId(PluginLicensedUser.java:11) at com.atlassian.plugins.license.service.AbstractLicenseUsageCollector.populateLicensedUserIdentity(AbstractLicenseUsageCollector.java:231) at com.atlassian.plugins.license.service.ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.getLicensedUser(ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.java:82) at com.atlassian.plugins.license.service.ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.lambda$getLicensedUsers$1(ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.java:58) at java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$3$1.accept(ReferencePipeline.java:193) at java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$2$1.accept(ReferencePipeline.java:175) at java.util.Spliterators$ArraySpliterator.forEachRemaining(Spliterators.java:948) at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:481) at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.wrapAndCopyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:471) at java.util.stream.ReduceOps$ReduceOp.evaluateSequential(ReduceOps.java:708) at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluate(AbstractPipeline.java:234) at java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline.collect(ReferencePipeline.java:499) at com.atlassian.plugins.license.service.ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.getLicensedUsers(ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.java:61) at com.atlassian.plugins.license.service.ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.lambda$getLicensedUsersProvider$0(ConfluenceLicenseUsageCollector.java:52) 
{code}

h3. Workaround

If the users are not necessary in the application, they can be removed either manually or by configuring the directory in a way that would filter them out. If they are necessary and the directory is external then check if the attribute used for external id is non-nullable and unique within that directory. While the issue generally should not occur for internal directories the external_id column in the cwd_user table could be populated manually for those users.
fields.summary: Calculating licenses for users with empty external ids fails

fields.description:

Starting Crowd immediately after the stop command causes duplicate nodes to appear in cluster
h3. Environment

(Optional - If Applicable)

{code:java}

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Currently, when the AD admin create a user account in the LDAP and configure a the account to use a [shared mailbox|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/collaboration/shared-mailboxes/shared-mailboxes?view=exchserver-2019] (feature provided by Microsoft AD), the user account is being synced as inactive. and not able to make the user account to active. 

This is because Microsoft AD use the inactive status of the account to identify if that account is using a shared mailbox.
* [why user associated with a shared mailbox is always a disabled user account|https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/ceb144c0-7cee-487f-a35e-c0301418660f/why-user-associated-with-a-shared-mailbox-is-always-a-disabled-user-account?forum=onlineservicesexchange]

h3. Suggestion
implement the feature in Crowd to allow user account use shared mailbox and make the user status active.
fields.summary: Support user account to use a shared mailbox

fields.description:
Currently in Crowd, we have a debug logging to log and list out the users that are counted towards the Crowd license:
* [How to list users who are counted towards the Crowd License|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowdkb/how-to-list-users-who-are-counted-towards-the-crowd-license-747834973.html]

It's great to have this feature on the UI instead, just like the centralized license for Applications connected to Crowd is showing.

Reasons:
* Usability - it will be easier for admins to obtain this list 
* GDPR - Usernames will not be logged into the logs
fields.summary: Have a UI to list out Crowd Licensed Users

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The is a JVM parameter in Crowd, {{-Dcrowd.polling.startdelay}}, that should delay the sync of any external directories upon startup by the number of miliseconds specified in the JVM parameter.

This was working until Crowd 2.12.0.  Since then, this parameter only effects the start of the first sync once the directory is enabled.
h3. Environment
 * Crowd 2.12.0 or later
 * Remote directory such as LDAP or AD

h3. Steps to Reproduce

 # Start Crowd
 # Add the remote directory
 ## Set the sync interval to 10 minutes
 ## You can see the directory will sync every 10 minutes
 # Stop Crowd
 # Add the JVM parameter, and set it to 900000ms (15 minutes)
 # Start Crowd

h3. Expected Results

The next sync should take place at least 15 minutes after start-up.  This is the case in Crowd versions pre 2.12.0
h3. Actual Results

The sync will continue at its normal pattern, every 10 minutes, based off the last successful sync time.
h3. Notes

It appears, in 2.12.0 and later, that this parameter is only respected when adding a new directory.  For example:
 * When adding a new directory in Crowd, Crowd should automatically sync it within a few minutes of the directory being added.
 * If the JVM parameter is set, Crowd will respect that delay, and only sync once the delay has expired.

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: crowd.polling.startdelay JVM parameter is not respected

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The '*Change password*' feature for an application in Crowd does not result in the password to be updated. The password hash in the DB remains the same when checked using this query:
{code:java}
select credential from cwd_application where application_name='confluence';{code}
In your external application (e.g. Confluence), if you try to change the application password to the new password, Confluence will prompt that the authentication failed. If you switch back to the original password, the authentication will pass.
h3. Environment

Crowd 3.5.0. Does not occur in Crowd 3.4.4.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Confluence application in Crowd and set the password to '*test*'.
 # In Confluence, create a Crowd directory and set the application password to '*test*'.
 # The directory creation and sync will be successful.
 # In Crowd, change the password via '*Change password*' to '*confluence*'.
 # In Confluence, edit the Crowd directory and insert the new password '*confluence*' to the '*Application Password*' field.
 # Click on '*Test Settings*'.

h3. Expected Results

The password will be updated and the directory settings could be saved.
h3. Actual Results

You will see this error in the UI.
{quote}Connection test failed. Response from the server:
 com.atlassian.crowd.exception.InvalidAuthenticationException: Application failed to authenticate
{quote}
h3. Workaround
# Update the {{cwd_application.credential}} field directly with the password hash. For example:
 {code:java}UPDATE cwd_application 
SET credential = '{PKCS5S2}pm5SMA8ZmbKl5K0s/dLcQllxpZFQ6M3RiWRsarEx7Mru9R2Ox0ktWZaHof+euNKG' 
WHERE application_name='confluence';{code}
# Create a new application in Crowd with the correct password.
fields.summary: Changing the application password does not work

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Logging out from the linked application (Confluence, Jira, Bitbucket etc.) to Crowd will trigger XSRF error in logs with a display of session information.

h3. Environment
Crowd 3.4.5
Confluence 6.15.4
Use Crowd SSO as user directory in Confluence.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Enable SSO from Crowd on Confluence, with linked user directory.
# Login to Confluence.
# Logout from Confluence

h3. Expected Results
Nothing will be logged in Crowd logs when you log in or logout.

h3. Actual Results
The crowd will Log XSRF warning and it will display session information.

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-crowd.log file:
{noformat}
2019-07-25 16:11:59,525 http-nio-6345-exec-8 WARN [common.security.jersey.XsrfResourceFilter] XSRF failure not being enforced for request: http://localhost:6345/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/session/4560Zf6Bdtr5J... , origin: null , referrer: null, method: DELETE
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Logging out from the linked application to Crowd will trigger XSRF error in logs with display of session information.

fields.description:
Twice while someone was sitting next to me I've logged-in to Crowd and, out of habit, typed TAB and SPACE to check the "Remember me" checkbox, but not noticing that the eyeball icon to show password was there, that key combination just exposed my password instead.  WTFx1000!  Note:  I was not on a mobile device when logging in, but my laptop.

There is no reason for the show password feature on a desktop device/view.  Please fix this ASAP!
fields.summary: Remove the "show password" "eye icon" on the login page

fields.description:
Since Crowd 3.3.0, Group Level Administration was introduced in Crowd Data Center. This included the introduction of new Rest API endpoints that cater for this functionality.
 This includes the following end points. 
 /admin/1.0/group-level-admin
 and
 /admin/1.0/groups/

Some of the new APIs include the {{groupid}} parameter. The documentation, however, does not explain how to obtain this nor there is any REST function that helps in obtaining the ID.

This causes a confusion, where users who would like to use these endpoints think that this groupid is actually the groupid from the database.

This is not the case, however, as based on the discussion with the Crowd product team, the groupid is obtained by combining the User Directory the group belongs to and the group name. The group name should be in the base64 URL safe encoding format.

So for example if directory id is 163841 and the group name's encoding is Y29uZmx1ZW5jZS11c2Vycw then the REST will look like something like this.
 * {{rest/admin/1.0/groups/163841-Y29uZmx1ZW5jZS11c2Vycw}}

To convert the group name to Base 64 Encoder URL safe format users will need to code their own converter or use online tools such as
 * [Base 64 Encoder (100% client-side) :: OpinionatedGeek|https://opinionatedgeek.com/Codecs/Base64Encoder]

h3. Proposed Resolution:

Explain the process of obtaining the groupid in the official REST API documentation.
fields.summary: How to obtain the groupid parameter in Group Leave Administration specific REST APIs is not clearly explained

fields.description:
Since Crowd 3.3.0, Group Level Administration was introduced in Crowd Data Center. This included the introduction of new Rest API endpoints that cater for this functionality. 

This includes the following end points. 
/admin/1.0/group-level-admin
and
/admin/1.0/groups/

The documentation, however, does not explicitly mention that these are only Data Center specific.  

* https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-crowd/3.4.0/REST/
* https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-crowd/3.3.0/REST/ 

When admins attempt to implement the said endpoints, using a server license, the following is returned

{code}
{
    "reason": "OPERATION_FAILED",
    "message": "This feature requires Data Center license"
}
{code}

h5. Resolution 
Explicitly mention that these endpoints are Data Center specific.
fields.summary: Crowd REST API documentation does not specify that certain end points are only Data Center specific

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

This issue is related to this closed bug report: [CWD\-5077: Crowd does not always auto add application groups when SSO is enabled (fixed in Crowd 3.3.0)|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-5077]. 

Although, the bug report was technically closed and fixed. There is one scenario where it fails. Users are not automatically added to the application groups if.
* SSO is enabled and,
* The user already exist in the application. 


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate Crowd to Confluence with SSO Enabled
# In Confluence, ensure that a user A already exists and not assigned to any group.
# Head over to Crowd > Applications > Confluence
# Click on the Directories & Groups tab
# In the Actions menu, click Configure automatically assigned groups and select {{confluence-administrators}} group or any group that has the permission to login to Confluence. Ensure that user A exists in that group.
# Save your changes.
# Navigate to Confluence and attempt to login as the user. 

h3. Expected Results
The user A is able to login because the user is assigned automatically to or to {{confluence-administrators}}

h3. Actual Results
The user A cannot login, because the the user is not assigned automatically to the {{confluence-administrators}}

h3. Note 
The above was tested on Crowd with Confluence, but based on the customer's experience, this might be happening in all other applications. 

h3. Workaround
* Ensure users are not synchronized to Confluence before both
** Configuring automatically assigned groups options. 
** Users attempting to login.
fields.summary: Automatically assigned groups feature does not work when SSO is enabled and the user already exist in the application

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Centralized license visibility plugin ([https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1220745/centralized-license-visibility]) counts inactive users in Jira as users who consume license, hence, the total count of license consuming users in Crowd 3.5 for Jira is more than actual count.
h3. Environment
 * Crowd 3.5 DC
 * Jira

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Crowd 3.5 DC and the above mentioned plugin in Jira which has at least one inactive user with at least one application role
 # Create Application Link to Jira from Crowd, and associate the Application Link with Jira application in Crowd
 # Wait for sometime, in order to allow Crowd sync license usage data from Jira application
 # Check the total number of licensed users in using 'Licenses' tab in Crowd
 # Check the total number of licensed users in your Jira

h3. Expected Results

Count of licensed users in Crowd's 'Licenses' tab and Jira licensing information should be same.
h3. Actual Results

Crowd will show more user count than Jira, since it will count the inactive users as well.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Centralized license visibility plugin counts inactive users with application role in Jira towards license consumption

fields.description:
When a directory has the *Use* *nested groups* option set. Crowd will synchronize groups from the external directory and will allow for nested groups in the external directory to be synchronized to Crowd. 

The current implementation, will synchronize all the groups and the sub groups. Some Crowd admins would prefer that the parent group will be the only group synchronized and all users who are members of that parent group and all users belonging its sub-groups, consolidated into one list. The sub-groups/child groups will not be synchronized. Only their users will be synchronized and consolidated and will be displayed as members of the parent group.
fields.summary: Provide a feature where Crowd is able to synchronize and display nested groups from external directories as flat list.

fields.description:
Many concurrent SSO authenticated request may significantly slow down Crowd.

Consider general improvement of SSO-flow including caching, avoiding doing unnecessary processing (related to database specifically) etc.

 

Areas for improvements:
 * While processing requests incoming from a connected application, Crowd will update the authentication token (which was provided by the application) every single request just to update the last_accessed_time column. This operation is not required to happen that often. For example such a token could be updated every couple of seconds to avoid unnecessary sql update statements which create additional load on the database and also saturate the database connection pool in Crowd.
 * During verification if the connected application making request to Crowd is correctly authenticated, Crowd creates many instances of ApplicationImpl in the same thread. Because ApplicationImpl holds a bunch of references to other tables (directories, webhooks etc) instantiating it turns out to be quite time consuming (to fetch data from the db). The ApplicationImpl instance could be created only once and stored in a thread-local manner.
 *  AutoGroupAdderListener is not optimized as it processes SSO logins related events twice, but it could do it only once. According to internal benchmarks it has a significant performance hit for user authentication requests.
fields.summary: Improve general SSO authentication performance

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Nested Groups can be enabled on both, Crowd server and connected applications using Embedded Crowd.
On some connected applications, doing operations with nested groups (i.e. permissions validation on Confluence) may be expensive.

When Embedded Crowd synchronizes a directory with Crowd, it uses the {{/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/group/membership}} REST API method.
If we have the below hierarchy in the LDAP server, then Crowd will pass it along to the connected application without any modifications.
{quote}
+ *GroupProject1*
++ aduser003
++ *GroupTeam1*
+++ aduser001
+++ aduser002
{quote}

This forces the connected application to be aware of nested groups and still perform expensive operations to accomplish its tasks.

h3. Suggested Solution
When nested groups is enabled in Crowd, there could be a configuration to always pass along to the connected applications a flattened groups memberships in a way that the connected application isn't aware the nested groups configuration exists.

In the previous example, instead of passing the hierarchy below
{quote}
+ *GroupProject1*
++ aduser003
++ *GroupTeam1*
+++ aduser001
+++ aduser002
{quote}

Crowd could send a flattened list of users x groups memberships as below
{quote}
    + *GroupProject1*
    ++ aduser003
    ++ aduser001
    ++ aduser002

    + *GroupTeam1*
    ++ aduser001
    ++ aduser002
{quote}

This would relief the connected application from expensive nested groups calculation, leaving this task to Crowd when Synchronization occurs.
 
h3. Workaround 
_There's no workaround so far._
fields.summary: When nested groups are enabled, provide flattened groups' membership when synchronizing with connected applications

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Upgrading Crowd via XML Data Transfer can reactivate a disabled user from OpenLDAP.

h3. Environment
Crowd 3.x.x
OpenLDAP

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Crowd 3.1.1 and connect with OpenLDAP directory.
# Synchronise the OpenLDAP directory.
# Disable one of the user from OpenLDAP directory.
# Generate the XML Backup.
# Upgrade Crowd by following the steps in [Upgrading Crowd via XML Data Transfer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/upgrading-crowd-via-xml-data-transfer-213519481.html]

h3. Expected Results
OpenLDAP user remain disabled

h3. Actual Results
OpenLDAP user reactivate after the upgrade.

Audit Logs shows that the user is synchronised from OpenLDAP and recreated in crowd as Active user:
* !auditlog.png|thumbnail!



h3. Workaround
Upgrade Crowd using [Method 1: Automatic database upgrade|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/upgrading-crowd-22544441.html]
fields.summary: Upgrading Crowd via XML Data Transfer reactivate disabled user from OpenLDAP -  CVE-2019-20902

fields.description:
h2. Context

When Crowd connects to an Active Directory server, it can synchronize the active or inactive status of an account from AD. This is based off of the {{UserAccountControl}} parameter in AD.
h2. Suggestion

This parameter is currently hard-coded in Crowd, and cannot be customized. Some AD setups may use a custom field, and doing so will currently break the ability of Crowd to pull this status down during a sync. Crowd Admins will instead need to manually mark users in Crowd as active or inactive.
fields.summary: Allow the active/inactive field from Active Directory to be customizable in Crowd

h3. Notes

One can click 'Continue' multiple times on any other screen and then Crowd will report that a given setup step has already been completed
h3. Workaround

Don't click 'Continue' more than once
fields.summary: Clicking the "Continue" button multiple times when setting up database causes startup failure

fields.description:
Due to the bug reported in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-5409, *disabled* OpenLDAP user have been *enabled* after upgrading Crowd.

Therefore, it is important to include an important note in the [Crowd Upgrade Guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/upgrading-crowd-22544441.html] for precaution.
fields.summary: Improvement on Crowd Upgrade Documentation

fields.description: Add the ability to allow crowd to send plain text e-mails instead of HTML/Rich Text.
fields.summary: Add plain text e-mail configuration option

fields.description:
Password expiration mail template currently has the following variables:


 * $username (username/s)
 * $daysToPasswordExpiration (days until password expire)
 * $changePasswordlink (change password link)
 * $admincontact (administrator contact details)
 * $deploymenttitle (crowd deployment title)
 * $date (message date)

 

$username should be the actual account username, currently it appears to be FirstName LastName.  To match the other templates $firstname and $lastname should be added to allow for more verbose emails if wanted.
fields.summary: Update password expiration template emails

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Updating or adding "Subject prefix" in Mail Configuration page, then reloading the page, will clear the input field for "Subject prefix".

h3. Environment
Crowd 3.4.4

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure mail server, test and apply changes.
# Then configure "Subject prefix"
# Apply changes and reload the page.

h3. Expected Results
Same data will be visible.

h3. Actual Results
Only "Subject prefix" input field is empty.

h3. Workaround
 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Applying email subject prefix on email server configuration and then reloading the page will clear the field of update.

fields.description:
If you’re using SAML authentication with Crowd in Confluence or Jira and you encounter a restricted area in one of these applications, you’ll be redirect to Crowd to authenticate. Once you authenticate in Crowd, you’ll be redirected back to your application. Since you don’t have permissions to access that particular area, the application redirects you again to Crowd this way creating an infinite loop. 

 
h3. Workaround

there is no workaround for this issue.
fields.summary: Infinite-authentication-loop in Confluence and Jira

fields.description: !user-directories-fisheye.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Rename 'FishEye' references to 'Fisheye' in Crowd

fields.description:
It would be very useful to have Crowd REST API that could return the license details (expiry date etc.) and number of users counting towards Crowd license.

This will allow administrators to easily keep track of the users that is counting towards the license and also to allow for easy monitoring of Crowd server user counts.

The following rest resources exist in newer versions of Confluence should also be available for Crowd:
{code}
/rest/license/1.0/license/userCount
/rest/license/1.0/license/remainingSeats
/rest/license/1.0/license/maxUsers
{code}
fields.summary: Crowd REST API to retrieve License and user count Details

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The group name with Cyrillic characters is not accepted by the Crowd when using MSSQL, it will throw the following error message when trying to create the group: 
{noformat}
2019-05-13 21:38:54,161 http-nio-8096-exec-21 ERROR [console.action.group.ViewGroup] Group <*********> does not exist
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.GroupNotFoundException: Group <*********> does not exist
	at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.group.GroupDAOHibernate.findByName(GroupDAOHibernate.java:148)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.group.GroupDAOHibernate.findByName(GroupDAOHibernate.java:51)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.AbstractInternalDirectory.findGroupByName(AbstractInternalDirectory.java:699)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.AbstractInternalDirectory.findGroupByName(AbstractInternalDirectory.java:63)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.findGroupByName(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:464)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:333)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:190)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:157)
	at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor$1.proceedWithInvocation(TransactionInterceptor.java:99)
	at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionAspectSupport.invokeWithinTransaction(TransactionAspectSupport.java:282)
	at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor.invoke(TransactionInterceptor.java:96)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:179)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:213)
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy97.findGroupByName(Unknown Source)
{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Crowd with SQL server. 
# Create a group with Cyrillic characters such as Greek or Russian.

h3. Expected Results
The group should be created normally. 

h3. Actual Results
* It throws an error on the UI with the message "Group <*********> does not exist"
* The group name column in the table cwd_group is showing question marks for all Cyrillic characters.

h3. Notes
The root cause of the issue is that all string type related column in Crowd is still using the data type VARCHAR instead of NVARCHAR, which does not support the Cyrillic characters.

This issue apparently causes the user or the group creation failure on both manual creation and synchronization from any external user repositories. 

h3. Workaround
For the group name, please use the following: 
# Shutdown Crowd. 
# Backup the database. 
# Delete the row that contain the Cyrillic characters.
# Run the following queries to change the datatype: 
{code}
alter table cwd_group drop CONSTRAINT uk_group_name_dir_id; 
alter table cwd_group alter column lower_group_name nvarchar(255);
alter table cwd_group alter column group_name nvarchar(255);
alter table cwd_group add CONSTRAINT uk_group_name_dir_id UNIQUE (lower_group_name, directory_id);
{code}
# Restart Crowd and try to create the group or trigger the synchronzation again.
fields.summary: Group name with cyrillic characters can not be created when using MSSQL

fields.description:
According to [Crowd 3.3 Release Notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-3-3-release-notes-958762272.html]:
{quote}
*Multiple server alert addresses*
From now on, Crowd lets you configure multiple server alert email addresses, so whenever some alert occur, every of these emails receive notification. 
{quote}
(which relates to [CWD-5018|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-5018])

However, the document [Configuring your Mail Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/configuring-your-mail-server-17956965.html] still mentions *Server alert email* as a field that could only receive one e-mail address. The screenshot must also be updated.

It is also unclear about how should the e-mail addresses be separated in the field (comma, semi-colon, etc).
fields.summary: Improve "Configuring your Mail Server" document

fields.description:
h2. Summary
There's no public facing documentation instructing how to update Crowd Data Center license when it expired.

h2. Why is this Needed
Suppose a Cluster of 4 nodes, where _crowd.cfg.xml_ is present with License key in both Local Home and Shared Home, does updating an expired Data Center License through Crowd UI updates all nodes?

Does one needs to restart all nodes for the changes to take effect? Is there a need of manual intervention to update _crowd.cfg.xml_ on Local Home directories of nodes or updating through the UI updates them all?

h3. Workaround
Follow [Moving to Crowd Data Center|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/moving-to-crowd-data-center-935372358.html], apply the license through the UI and restart all nodes for them to pick-up the needed new license.

If by any reason this doesn't works, open _crowd.cfg.xml_ on all nodes and ensure that they all have the new license key listed under the following property:
{code}
<property name="license">
{code}
fields.summary: Updating Data Center License Documentation

fields.description:
Currently Crowd does not have the feature that notifies users when their passwords are modified. This feature is a normal security feature and is a basic security audit requirement.

At least Crowd should send email notifications to users when their passwords has been changed by themselves or system admins.

This feature might also come with a configuration capability. The configuration will facilitate notifications to be sent to either the System Admin, the user or both when the System Admin or the user changes the password.
fields.summary: Provide the feature where users and system admins get notified via email when a password in Crowd is changed.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The Password Expiration Reminder mail template is defined as the following:

{code:java}
Hello $username,

your password will expire in $daysToPasswordExpiration day(s). Please use the following link to change your password to avoid losing access to Crowd and connected applications.

$changePasswordlink

$deploymenttitle administrator
{code} 

The above has the $username macro. This macro, is supposed to refer to the user's account username like how it is in other mail templates. In its current implementation, the $username macro refer to the  firstname lastname value.

h3. Expected Results
The $username macro should refer to the user's username. Also, it would be better that the template also have a separate macro for $firstname and $lastname.

h3. Actual Results
The $username macro refers to the "firstname lastname" value.

h3. Workaround
There is currently no known workaround.
fields.summary: The $username macro in the Password Expiration Reminder mail template does note refer to the account's username

fields.description:
Add a small note in [https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/upgrading-crowd-22544441.html]  documentation to include upgrade recommendation involving Atlassian Stack.

For example, a suggestion to upgrade Crowd in the first place or last if we have Crowd connected with Integrated Application (Jira, Confluence and Bitbucket) that also need to be upgrade to the latest version.
fields.summary: Improvement on Crowd Upgrade Guide

fields.description:
In Crowd Data Center Group-level administration view shows Directory name in Directory column, which can be confusing for a common user. They do not have capabilities to see Directory configurations, as it is a sysadmin level configuration.
Crowd Data Center should have capability to hide this Directory column, and that should be hide by default.
fields.summary: Group-level Administration menu should not show Directory name

fields.description:
Crowd and Crowd Data Center had the pdkinstall development plugin incorrectly enabled in release builds. Attackers who can send unauthenticated or authenticated requests to a Crowd or Crowd Data Center instance can exploit this vulnerability to install arbitrary plugins, which permits remote code execution on systems running a vulnerable version of Crowd or Crowd Data Center.

*Affected versions:*
 * All versions of Crowd from version 2.1.0 before 3.0.5 (the fixed version for 3.0.x), from version 3.1.0 before 3.1.6 (the fixed version for 3.1.x), from version 3.2.0 before 3.2.8 (the fixed version for 3.2.x), from version 3.3.0 before 3.3.5 (the fixed version for 3.3.x), and from version 3.4.0 before 3.4.4 (the fixed version for 3.4.x) are affected by this vulnerability.

h4. *Fix:*
 * Crowd and Crowd Data Center version 3.4.4 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download]
 * Crowd and Crowd Data Center versions 3.0.5, 3.1.6, 3.2.8, and 3.3.5 are available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download-archive]

 
*Mitigation*

Atlassian recommends that you upgrade to the latest version. However, this issue can be mitigated as per the following instructions:
 # Stop Crowd
 # Find and delete any pdkinstall-plugin jar files from the Crowd *installation directory and the data directory*
 # Remove the pdkinstall-plugin jar file from <Crowd installation directory>/crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/atlassian-bundled-plugins.zip
 # Start Crowd
 # Check that there are no pdkinstall-plugin jar files in the *installation directory or the data directory.* 


For additional details, see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/3ADVOQ].
fields.summary: Crowd - pdkinstall development plugin incorrectly enabled - CVE-2019-11580

fields.description:
It will be really helpful to cache the data for the following queries as it has been fired on each user login: 
{noformat}
select attributes0_.directory_id as directory_id1_17_0_, attributes0_.attribute_value as attribute_value3_17_0_, attributes0_.attribute_name as attribute_name2_0_ from cwd_directory_attribute attributes0_ where attributes0_.directory_id=:1

select allowedope0_.app_dir_mapping_id as app_dir_mapping_id1_3_0_, allowedope0_.operation_type as operation_type2_3_0_ from cwd_app_dir_operation allowedope0_ where allowedope0_.app_dir_mapping_id=:1 
{noformat}
These queries are related with instantiation objects of `Directory` class and using getters on them, such as `getAttributes()`, `getAllowedOperations()` or getDirectoryMappings() on objects of `Application` class.

The cache should help to reduce the load on the database server side.
fields.summary: Adding new cache key for the directory attribute

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

First synchronization after bulk users rename takes longer time
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Bulk rename users (10k users) in Crowd or remote ldap directory
 # Synchronize Jira/Confluence/BBS application with Crowd

h3. Expected Results

Synchronization should not take several hours

 

*Business impact*

Renaming 10k users requires 10 hours additional outage in Crowd and connected apps just for synchronization
h3. Actual Results

Synchronization takes several (2-3) hours
h3. Workaround

No at the moment
fields.summary: After bulk users rename connected apps take longer time to synchronize

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When group name casing is changed in AD, it does not reflect in Crowd and the following WARN is found in the logs.

{code:java}
2019-04-08 21:40:08,023 Caesium-2-2 WARN [directory.synchronisation.cache.DefaultGroupActionStrategy] remote group name [ GroupONe ] casing differs from local group name [ Groupone ]. Group details will be kept updated, but the group name cannot be updated
{code}
 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an AD External User Directory in Crowd of type connector and then synchronize to Crowd.
# Check that all the groups in AD are synchronized. 
# In AD, change the casing of one of the groups for example from *Group One* to *Group one*
# In Crowd, synchronize the AD External Directory 

h3. Expected Results
The group *Group One* is renamed to *Group one*

h3. Actual Results
The group is not renamed and the following is found in the logs:
{code:title=atlassian-crowd.log}
2019-04-08 21:40:08,023 Caesium-2-2 WARN [directory.synchronisation.cache.DefaultGroupActionStrategy] remote group name [ Group one ] casing differs from local group name [ Group One ]. Group details will be kept updated, but the group name cannot be updated
{code}

h3. Workaround
One work around is as follows.
# In AD, totally rename the group to a different name for example Group One to Groupone
# Synchronise to Crowd, this will rename the group in Crowd to the new name
# Now, in AD rename the group to the original name but with the new casing.
fields.summary: Changing Group Name casing in AD, does not reflect in Crowd

fields.description:
*Problem*

Embedded Crowd does not support incremental synchronisation for directory connectors other than Active Directory.

Nevertheless, for all connectors the parameter is set to true :{{crowd.sync.incremental.enabled=true}} even if it is not supported. For AD, one has the option to disable it from the UI, but for other connectors this is not available.

*Consequences*
For all other connectors the incremental sync always kicks in, fails, since it is unsupported and triggers full synchronisation. This adds some overhead, as well as misleading noice in the logs (incremental sync always failing, where as it should not have been triggered).

*Proposed Solution*
For non AD connectors, set {{crowd.sync.incremental.enabled=false}}
fields.summary: Incremental synchronisation should be disabled  for non-AD connectors (embedded crowd)

fields.description:
h3. Background
From the [Crowd 3.4.0 Release Notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-3-4-release-notes-966041084.html]:

Crowd 3.4 brings you refreshed screen where you manage direct group members. We've introduced a totally new search box, dynamic table, and an easy way to quickly add and remove your users.
{quote}

This screen is not used when the directory contains nested groups

h3. Suggestion

fields.summary: Improve Group Management Screen for Directories Using Nested Groups

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

An administrator wants an option on Crowd internal directory to configure the application to enforce a minimum 24 hours password lifetime. The idea is to avoid having users resetting or updating their passwords during that period. This option is not available yet.

h3. Suggested Solution

Crowd should have a parameter inside its configuration tab to allow administrators to configure the application to enforce a minimum password lifetime before users could be allowed to reset or update the password again.

h3. Why this is important

An insufficiently long password lifetime allows authorized users to reuse old passwords with greater ease and frequency despite the password history feature. This more readily enables brute-force attacks and password predictability, elevating the attacker's chances to gain account access. A short or nonexistent password age would let a user repeatedly reset or update his password quickly enough to allow him to revert to an old password in a short period of time while still satisfying the unique password history requirement.
fields.summary: Option to enforce password lifetime before the local admin user can be allowed to reset or update the password again

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

After 3.3.0 customer is not able to configure LDAP failover on Crowd anymore.

The introduction of CWD-2768 has removed the ability Crowd had to configure LDAP failover on native Java method.

Customer understands this is a bug, as he lost funcionality with that fix.
h3. Environment

Customer upgrading Crowd from 3.2.0 to latest versions and found that he cannot use native support for LDAP node failover.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * application.xml would contain a line like this:
{code:java}
 <crowd.Directory-1.Attributes.ldap.url>ldap://1.1.1.1:389 ldap://10.125.88.239:389</crowd.Directory-1.Attributes.ldap.url>
{code}

 * On 3.2.0
 ## Access Directories, find one which would connect via LDAP
 ## Edit it and fill the URL field with the two address, for example:
{code:java}
ldap://1.1.1.1:389 ldap://10.125.88.239:389
{code}

 # 
 ## Save will work fine

 * On 3.3.4
 ## Access Directories, find one which would connect via LDAP
 ## URL field is not available anymore
 ## Trying to add two hostnames brings this error message:
{code:java}
Uncategorized exception occured during LDAP processing; nested exception is javax.naming.NamingException: Cannot parse url: abc:389 [Root exception is java.net.MalformedURLException: Not an LDAP URL: abc:389]
{code}
4. Tring to edit a Directory, on Connector tab, for one which has >1 URLs, list the following error:
{code:java}
Cause:
java.lang.RuntimeException: java.net.URISyntaxException: Illegal character in authority at index 7: ldap://1.1.1.1:389 ldap://10.125.88.239:389
Stack trace:
java.lang.RuntimeException: java.net.URISyntaxException: Illegal character in authority at index 7: ldap://1.1.1.1:389 ldap://10.125.88.239:389
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.LdapUrlData.fromURLAndMode(LdapUrlData.java:62)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.directory.UpdateConnectorConnection.execute(UpdateConnectorConnection.java:76)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
	at ognl.OgnlRuntime.invokeMethod(OgnlRuntime.java:899)
	at ognl.OgnlRuntime.callAppropriateMethod(OgnlRuntime.java:1544)
	at ognl.ObjectMethodAccessor.callMethod(ObjectMethodAccessor.java:68)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.ognl.accessor.XWorkMethodAccessor.callMethodWithDebugInfo(XWorkMethodAccessor.java:98)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.ognl.accessor.XWorkMethodAccessor.callMethod(XWorkMethodAccessor.java:90)
	at ognl.OgnlRuntime.callMethod(OgnlRuntime.java:1620)
	at ognl.ASTMethod.getValueBody(ASTMethod.java:91)
	at ognl.SimpleNode.evaluateGetValueBody(SimpleNode.java:212)
	at ognl.SimpleNode.getValue(SimpleNode.java:258)
	at ognl.Ognl.getValue(Ognl.java:470)
	at ognl.Ognl.getValue(Ognl.java:434)
{code}

 * UI error screenshot:
 !image-2019-03-14-19-14-41-836.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results

Customer expected to be able to edit the Connector fields to keep that functionality.
h3. Actual Results

Not able to access Connector tab while Editing Directory due to error (mentioned above).
h3. Workaround
 * The failover still works, what is impacted is the editing of the Directory via UI

Customer can:
 * Update the database directly to add 2 hosts:
{code:java}
UPDATE cwd_directory_attribute
set attribute_value = 'ldap://1.1.1.1:389 ldap://10.125.88.239:389'
WHERE attribute_name = 'ldap.url' AND directory_id=<ID>;
{code}

 * Update the database to list only one directory in order to edit the parameters via UI, and then update back to revert to 2 directories.
fields.summary: Editing Directory Connector tab shows error when 2 LDAP URL are listed

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Crowd can deadlock under heavy load when sending requests using application/xml response types. The Crowd Client is hardcoded to use application/xml response types.
 
h3. Notes
This is a known issue with Jersey: [Stuck threads under heavy load · Issue #3460 · jersey/jersey · GitHub|https://github.com/jersey/jersey/issues/3460]

h3. Solution
Switch from application/xml response type to application/json in the Crowd Client.
fields.summary: Crowd dead-locks under heavy load

fields.description:
h4. Issue summary
# When a crowd directory is connected to an application like Jira or Confluence with "Read\Write" permission, these application's admins will be able to Edit these users.
# These changes are registered in Crowd's Audit logs, but it mentions the *Author* as the application name alone, and not the admin who made the changes in the application.

h4. Improvement
# It would be good to know who exactly made the changes in the application, in Crowd's Audit log.

h4. Current Behavior
# Changes made by application admins appear in Crowd's Audit log as Auhor="Application Name".

h4. Expected Behavior
# Changes made by application admin appear in Crowd's Audit logs as Auhor="USERNAME".
fields.summary: Explicitly mention user who made changes in Audit log's Author field

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If a group has 2 (or more) spaces in a row in its name, the XML Backup and automated backup will trim those extra spaces down to 1. This could result in duplicate groups as well as groups not matching downstream applications
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Crowd
 # Set up two groups (group names below are using - to represent a space character for ease of reading):
 ** {{test-group}}
 ** {{test--group}}
 # Run a Backup of Crowd
 # Try to restore the backup to the same or a different Crowd instance

h3. Expected Results

The import/restore will succeed.
h3. Actual Results

The import/restore will fail due to duplicate group names, OR the import will succeed but the group name will have changed.

*If the import fails due to duplicates:*

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-crowd.log file:
{noformat}
ERROR [atlassian.crowd.migration.GroupMapper] Could not add com.atlassian.crowd.model.group.InternalGroup@7faf32d0[id=15204648,name=test group,type=GROUP,active=true
{noformat}
Another error will also be thrown indicating a violation of a unique key constraint has happened. Eventually, we will then see:
{noformat}
ERROR [console.action.setup.Import] Error importing XML data
com.atlassian.crowd.migration.ImportException: Could not replicate the entire batch using the BatchProcessor.
{noformat}
In the XML file generated by the backup, we can see the extra space was removed:
{code:java|title=XML File}
    <group>
      <directoryId>98305</directoryId>
      <id>720898</id>
      <name>test group</name>
      <createdDate>Fri Mar 01 05:53:09 +0000 2019</createdDate>
      <updatedDate>Fri Mar 01 05:53:09 +0000 2019</updatedDate>
      <active>true</active>
      <description></description>
      <type>GROUP</type>
      <attributes/>
    </group>
    <group>
      <directoryId>98305</directoryId>
      <id>720897</id>
      <name>test group</name>
      <createdDate>Fri Mar 01 05:52:59 +0000 2019</createdDate>
      <updatedDate>Fri Mar 01 05:52:59 +0000 2019</updatedDate>
      <active>true</active>
      <description></description>
      <type>GROUP</type>
      <attributes/>
    </group>
{code}
h3. Notes

Extra spaces seem to only be possible in between words. Crowd will not allow the creation of groups with leading or trailing spaces.
h3. Workaround
h4. Option 1 - Remove The Group (if unused)
# Run the below DB query to get a list of all groups that have 2 (or more) spaces in their name:
{code:java}
select * from cwd_group where group_name LIKE '%  %';
{code}
# Check to see if any users are assigned to this group, using the {{id}} returned in the previous query:
{code:java}
select * from cwd_membership where parent_id = <id from above>;
{code}
# If no results are returned, then you can safely delete this group and re-run the export. If results are returned, then the group may be in use. Check downstream applications (Jira, Confluence, etc) to see if permissions or access is based on membership in this group. If so, proceed to Option 2

h4. Option 2 - Manually Modify the XML File
 # Open the XML file and do a search for the group ID (found in the first query above). You will need to manually change the group name for every entry in a {{<group>}} or {{<membership>}} parent tag.
 (!) Do not do a global find/replace, as if you have duplicate directories, it will change both, and the issue will still exist
 # Save the file, and re-run the import.
 # Groups (with extra spaces) will be imported now.
fields.summary: XML backup trims duplicate spaces from group names

fields.description:
h2. Problem Description

According to the REST API documentation for version 3.2.5, it should be possible to retrieve paged or paginated responses.

However, when requests are made in the following manner

{code}
curl http://crowd/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/group/user/direct?groupname=jira-users&max-results=5&start-index=0\\ 
{code}

We only receive a JSON response containing the first 5 users; there is no isLastPage or nextPage information.

The documentation in this regard seems contradictory - in the section on Pagination, it says:

{quote}
"Clients can use the limit and start query parameters to retrieve the desired number of results."
{quote}

Additionally in the various method documentation, e.g. https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-crowd/3.2.5/REST/ it says that "max-results" and "start-index" will provide this function.

h2. Action points
If this endpoint cannot return paginated data, then the documentation should be amended
fields.summary: Crowd REST API pagination does not function as documented

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When editing a directory Connector in Crowd, there is a button to change the LDAP password as shown in the image below: 
!change_password.png|thumbnail!

When you click on Change Password, “Cancel password change” appears in plain text, as shown below: 
!cancel_change.png|thumbnail!

It is not clear that this is a button until you hover over it, as shown below: 
!cancel_change_button.png|thumbnail!

This leads to confusion that the password change cannot be cancelled.

h3. Suggested Solution
Make the “Cancel Password Change” option a button, instead of plain text. 

h3. Why this is important
This issue has potential to cause outages for users because the password changes and they are unaware they can pull those changes back.
fields.summary: Improve password change options for directory connector

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
It is possible for an admin to set a Crowd account's {{invalidPasswordAttempts}} to a negative number, which bypasses normal password failure protections.

h3. Environment
Tested on Crowd 3.3.3

h3. Steps to Reproduce
* As admin, select an account and set the {{invalidPasswordAttempts}} to -10, then save changes.
* In a private window, attempt to log into that account with the wrong password.
* Go back to the Crowd admin window and refresh the account attributes page for the account in question. The {{invalidPasswordAttempts}} value will now be -9.

h3. Purposed Change
Validate the attribute value field, or automatically adjust a negative number to zero.
fields.summary: invalidPasswordAttempts can be set to negative number
